content: Most of the funding for HUD comes from annual appropriations by Congress to address housing problems for low-income households. Rental assistance programs like Public Housing, Section 8 Vouchers, and Section 8 project-based rental assistance are key, along with block grant programs like HOME and Community Development Block Grants. HUD's non-emergency funding in FY2010 is mainly allocated to rental assistance programs, with HOME and Community Development Block Grants supporting housing and community development activities for low-income families. Specialized grant programs also cater to homeless individuals, including those with AIDS. The Federal Housing Administration insures mortgages for lower-income home buyers and developers of affordable rental buildings. FHA sustains itself through fees from insured borrowers. FHA collects fees from insured borrowers to sustain the insurance fund and offset administrative costs. Surplus funds have been used to support the HUD budget, including emergency funding for disaster recovery and economic stimulus programs. The economic stimulus legislation (P.L. 111-5) provided over $13 billion to HUD's programs in recent years, increasing regular funding by 57% in the past nine years. HUD's budget has seen year-over-year increases of 5% or more each year, with growth of nearly 10% in FY2009 and nearly 12% in FY2010. Adjusting for inflation, the growth rate has been significant. HUD's budget has had significant year-over-year increases, with growth of nearly 10% in FY2009 and nearly 12% in FY2010. Adjusting for inflation, the growth in "real" funding has been less robust, growing by about 17% over a nine-year period. Most of the growth in HUD's budget has come in the last two years. HUD's funding is made up of several components, including regular annual appropriations and emergency appropriations. HUD's annual funding, or budget authority, consists of regular annual appropriations, emergency appropriations, rescissions, and offsets. The funding for HUD's programs and activities mainly comes from regular annual appropriations, also known as discretionary appropriations. Congress may also provide emergency appropriations in response to disasters. In some years, Congress provides emergency appropriations through HUD's programs, usually in response to disasters. These funds are separate from regular appropriations and are subject to limits on new discretionary funding. Ways to stay within these limits include providing less in regular appropriations or finding offsets. Rescissions are used to offset a portion of HUD's regular annual appropriations. The cost of HUD's regular annual appropriations acts is offset through rescissions and offsetting receipts and collections. The total net budget authority for HUD is determined by the interaction between new appropriations and offsets provided through rescissions, receipts, and collections. Net budget authority is the estimated "cost" of the HUD budget. The net budget authority for HUD is the estimated "cost" of the budget, determined by new appropriations and offsets like rescissions and receipts. The total net budget authority increased 57% from over $29 billion to over $46 billion between FY2002 and FY2010. Between FY2002 and FY2010, net non-emergency budget authority for HUD increased by 57%, reaching over $46 billion. This growth was not solely due to increased appropriations for HUD programs, as regular annual appropriations only grew by 37% during this period. Between FY2002 and FY2010, net non-emergency budget authority for HUD increased by 57%, reaching over $46 billion. The growth in regular appropriations grew by only 37%, with decreases in offsetting receipts and collections and rescinded amounts contributing to the increase in net budget authority. The 37% growth in regular appropriations is mainly due to growth in HUD's Section 8 voucher program. The 37% growth in regular appropriations from FY2002 to FY2010 is largely due to the increase in HUD's Section 8 voucher and project-based rental assistance programs, which account for the majority of the HUD budget. Appropriations for Section 8 programs grew by over 70%, while funding for other HUD programs only grew by 8%.
